docs.lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economist at Princeton.

headline.main: Why Does U.S. Health Care Cost So Much? (Part II: Indefensible Administrative Costs)

docs.abstract: One reason the United States spends so much on health care is that the administrative overhead load is huge by international standards.

docs.lead_paragraph: As a new bout of fear gripped the financial markets, stocks fell sharply again on Thursday, continuing a months-long plunge that has wiped out the gains of the last decade, Vikas Bajaj and Jack Healy reported.

docs.lead_paragraph: With Citigroup's stock now below $5, many investors seem to fear that the financial giant is tottering.

headline.main: Panic Over Citi Is Overblown, Bove Says

docs.abstract: With Citigroup's stock now below $5, many investors seem to fear that the financial giant is tottering. Richard X. Bove isn't one of them. In a research note published Thursday afternoon, the Ladenburg Thalmann banking analyst said that while he has gotten several calls asking if Citi is about to fail, he has counseled calm. [...]

docs.lead_paragraph: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg threatened to rescind the $400 tax-rebate checks that hundreds of thousands of New York City homeowners have come to expect as almost a birthright, Councilman Lewis A. Fidler was part of a chorus of critics.

headline.main: Mrs. Goldstein, Brooklyn's Joe the Plumber?

docs.abstract: In arguing for a continuation of the $400 property-tax rebates, Councilman Lewis A. Fidler cited the example of elderly residents who own their homes but are "cash-poor."
